questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the psychiatry OPD by his wife. During the interview, the patient says, " I dwell in Bangalore, I like eating more, my rabbit loves to explore." Which of the following thought disorders is he most likely exhibiting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Flight of ideas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In flight of ideas, the thoughts follow each other rapidly, and the connection between successive thoughts appears to be due to chance factors such as rhyming.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page 44.

questions.text: During a mental status examination, a patient is asked to explain the meaning of the proverb "A stitch in time saves nine." This test is primarily assessing which of the following cognitive functions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Abstract thinking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abstract thinking is the ability to form concepts and generalisations. Tests of abstract thinking include:
  • ➤ a. Proverb testing: Here, the patient is asked to explain the meaning of proverbs, and the answer is evaluated.
  • ➤ a. Proverb testing:
  • ➤ b. Similarities testing: Here, the patient is asked to explain the similarities between two objects, e.g., 'What is the similarity between a chair and a table? If the patient answers that 'both are pieces of furniture', it suggests the presence of abstract thinking; if the patient answers that 'both are kept on the floor', it suggests an absence of abstract thinking (known as concrete thinking).
  • ➤ b. Similarities testing:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 26.

questions.text: In the dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia, positive symptoms are thought to be caused by excessive dopamine in which neural pathway?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mesolimbic tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In schizophrenia, the positive symptoms are thought to be caused by excessive dopamine activity in the mesolimbic pathway, which is part of the brain's reward and emotion-processing system.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 361.

questions.text: A patient with treatment-resistant schizophrenia is started on clozapine. Which of the following monitoring schedules is correct for the first 6 months of treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Complete blood count once a month

options.label: B
options.text: Complete blood count once a week

options.label: C
options.text: Liver function tests once a week

questions.correct_answer: B. Complete blood count once a week
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Complete blood count once a week

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients on clozapine should have a complete blood count monitored weekly for the first 6 months of treatment to detect agranulocytosis early.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page 222.

questions.text: In shared delusional disorder (folie à deux), what is the recommended treatment for the secondary case?
questions.correct_answer: C. Separation from the primary case
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Separation from the primary case

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shared psychotic disorder is characterized by spread of delusions from one person to another. The individual who has the delusion (the primary case) is typically the influential member of a close relationship with a more suggestible person (the secondary case) who also develops the delusion. When two people are involved, the term “folie à deux” is used. Occasionally more than two individuals are involved (known as folie à trois, folie à quatre etc). Treatment includes separating the individuals as part of the treatment strategy, which often leads to resolution of the shared delusional beliefs in the secondary individual. Treatment with antipsychotic medications can be beneficial for the primary affected individual.
  • ➤ Shared psychotic disorder
  • ➤ “folie à deux”
  • ➤ folie à trois, folie à quatre
  • ➤ separating the individuals

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 347.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman develops auditory hallucinations, paranoid delusions, and disorganized speech over a period of two weeks following a significant personal loss. Her symptoms resolve completely within three weeks. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brief psychotic disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms lasting more than one day but less than one month, often following a significant stressor, with a full return to normal functioning afterward.

questions.text: Under the MHCA 2017, who can make an advance directive regarding mental healthcare and treatment?

options.label: D
options.text: Only family members of persons with mental illness

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Any adult person

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA) of 2017 allows any adult person to make an advance directive regarding their mental healthcare and treatment, emphasizing the autonomy and rights of individuals in making decisions about their mental health.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. He reports feeling hopeless and states that he "just wants to die." What is the most important factor to assess in determining the need for inpatient admission?

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of a specific suicide plan

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of a specific suicide plan
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Presence of a specific suicide plan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a specific suicide plan is the most crucial factor in assessing the need for inpatient admission following a suicide attempt, as it indicates a higher risk for completed suicide.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 812.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with major depressive disorder shows marked improvement in mood when good things happen, but quickly becomes depressed again. He also reports increased appetite and weight gain. Which specifier best describes his presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atypical features

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atypical depression, as its name implies, has features that deviate from classic presentations of depression. It is characterized by
  • ➤ Reversal of vegetative symptoms (i.e., increased sleep, appetite and weight), Presence of mood reactivity, Leaden paralysis (subjective feeling heaviness of limbs and difficulty in moving them) and Extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection.
  • ➤ Reversal of vegetative symptoms (i.e., increased sleep, appetite and weight),
  • ➤ Presence of mood reactivity,
  • ➤ Leaden paralysis (subjective feeling heaviness of limbs and difficulty in moving them) and
  • ➤ Extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection.
  • ➤ SSRIs & MAO- have shown efficacy in treating atypical depression, making them a potential therapeutic option for this subtype.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 197.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with severe depression and high suicide risk is not responding to pharmacotherapy. Which treatment modality should be considered as a first-line option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Electroconvulsive therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In severe cases of depression, particularly when accompanied by suicidal ideation and lack of response to medication, ECT is often the most effective and rapid treatment. ECT is indicated when there is a need for a quick and robust response, especially when there is a high risk of suicide.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 393.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with bipolar I disorder has been stable on lithium for several years. During a routine check-up, his serum creatinine is found to be elevated. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Reduce lithium dose and monitor renal function closely

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduce lithium dose and monitor renal function closely
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reduce lithium dose and monitor renal function closely

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with bipolar disorder on lithium therapy, the appropriate management of elevated serum creatinine includes reducing the lithium dose and closely monitoring renal function to prevent further nephrotoxicity.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14 th edition, Page 251.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with bipolar disorder needs mood stabilization. Which of the following medications is considered relatively safer during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lamotrigine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lamotrigine is considered a relatively safer option for mood stabilization during pregnancy compared to other mood stabilizers, which are associated with higher risks of teratogenic effects.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 692.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with alternating periods of elevated mood and depression, each lasting about 3-4 days, since last 5 years. She has never had a full manic or depressive episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cyclothymic Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclothymia is a milder form of bipolar disorder, in which manic symptoms and depressive symptoms occur, but they are never severe enough to make a diagnosis of mania or depression. The symptoms should last for at least 2 years.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 369.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man believes that his wife has been replaced by an identical-looking impostor. Which misidentification syndrome does this represent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Capgras syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delusional misidentification syndromes include Capgras syndrome, Fregoli’s syndrome, syndrome of intermetamorphosis and syndrome of subjective doubles.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Sim’s Symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 124-125.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia maintains an unusual arm position for several hours without any apparent reason. This symptom is best described as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posturing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posturing involves maintenance of a posture for a long period of time, commonly seen in catatonia.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page 345.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with schizophrenia experiences sudden contraction of neck muscles, causing her head to turn to one side. This acute side effect of antipsychotic medication is called:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute dystonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotics can be seen within minutes of receiving an injectable antipsychotic (also with oral antipsychotic). It is characterized by sudden contraction of a muscle group and can lead to symptoms like torticollis (twisting of the neck), oculogyric crisis (deviation of eyeballs), opisthotonos (extreme arching of the back), trismus (contraction of jaw muscles) or other dystonic reactions.
  • ➤ earliest side effect
  • ➤ sudden contraction
  • ➤ torticollis
  • ➤ oculogyric crisis
  • ➤ opisthotonos

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page 110-111.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with depressed mood, anhedonia, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating for the past 6 weeks after the divorce. She also reports feeling worthless and having recurrent thoughts of death. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Major depressive disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 381.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with bipolar I disorder has been stable on valproate for several years. She is planning to become pregnant. What is the most appropriate management regarding her medication?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue valproate at the current dose

options.label: D
options.text: Taper valproate and consider starting atypical antipsychotics

questions.correct_answer: D. Taper valproate and consider starting atypical antipsychotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Taper valproate and consider starting atypical antipsychotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When managing bipolar disorder in a woman planning to become pregnant, it is crucial to taper off teratogenic medications like valproate and consider safer alternatives, such as atypical antipsychotics, to minimize the risk to the fetus while maintaining mood stability.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14 th edition, Page 692.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of palpitations, sweating, and a fear of dying. These episodes occur suddenly and last about 10 minutes. She has become fearful of leaving her house. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Agoraphobia with panic disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack . Agoraphobia is defined as the fear of places from which escape might be difficult, this includes fear of open spaces, crowded places, enclosed places, traveling alone, and public transport. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.
  • ➤ Panic disorder
  • ➤ . Agoraphobia
  • ➤ Treatment

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical symptom of anxiety?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bradypnea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Symptoms of anxiety
  • ➤ Sweating, tremors, restlessness, tachycardia, mydriasis Increased urinary frequency, diarrhoea Hyperreflexia, cold clammy skin Feeling of nervousness
  • ➤ Sweating, tremors, restlessness, tachycardia, mydriasis
  • ➤ Increased urinary frequency, diarrhoea
  • ➤ Hyperreflexia, cold clammy skin
  • ➤ Feeling of nervousness

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 401.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has persistent worries about minor everyday issues and experiences muscle tension, poor concentration, and irritability. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Generalized anxiety disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generalized Anxiety Disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety which is generalized and persistent and is not restricted to any particular situation (also called freely floating anxiety ) and excessive worries. Patients are anxious about almost everything. This anxiety and worry is associated with the physical symptoms such as: restlessness, fatigue, poor concentration, irritability, muscle tension and insomnia. Treatment includes pharmacotherapy (SSRIs, benzodiazepines, buspirone and venlafaxine) and psychotherapy (CBT, supportive psychotherapy).
  • ➤ freely floating anxiety
  • ➤ excessive worries.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 405.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child refuses to go to school and experiences abdominal pain when separated from parents. This presentation is most consistent with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Separation anxiety disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Separation anxiety disorder is more common in children and is comparatively less common in adolescents/adults. It is characterized by a persistent and excessive fear of separation from prominent attachment figures (such as parents), which manifests in the form of reluctance to go to school, work, or away from home, or sleep in a separate room. If separation happens, the child may experience physical symptoms such as abdominal pain or headache and fear that something bad will happen to the attachment figures or to self. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 194-195.

questions.text: Which of the following behavioral techniques is not commonly used in the treatment of specific phobias?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thought stopping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exposure-based techniques like systematic desensitization, flooding, and participant modeling are commonly used in the treatment of specific phobias, while thought stopping is a cognitive technique not typically used for this purpose.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 408.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of obsessions in OCD?

options.label: A
options.text: They are considered a product of one's own mind

options.label: D
options.text: Patients try to resist or neutralize them

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) They are usually ego-syntonic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessions in OCD are ego-dystonic, causing significant anxiety and distress, and are recognized as a product of one's own mind. Patients often attempt to resist or neutralize these intrusive thoughts or urges.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page 46.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is preoccupied with a perceived flaw in his nose, which appears normal to others. He repeatedly checks his appearance in mirrors and has undergone multiple cosmetic surgeries with no satisfaction. He firmly believes his nose is deformed despite reassurance from others. Which of the following best describes his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Body dysmorphic disorder with good insight

options.label: B
options.text: Body dysmorphic disorder with absent insight/delusional beliefs

questions.correct_answer: B. Body dysmorphic disorder with absent insight/delusional beliefs
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Body dysmorphic disorder with absent insight/delusional beliefs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is characterized by the preoccupation with an imagined defect in body appearance. In case, a slight physical anomaly is present, the patient's concern for the same is exaggerated. The location of the imagined defect is usually hair, nose and skin.
  • ➤ imagined defect

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 416.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is preoccupied with the belief that he emits a foul odor, despite reassurance from others. He frequently changes clothes, uses excessive perfume, and avoids social situations. What is the recommended treatment approach for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SSRI and CBT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Olfactory reference disorder is a new diagnosis in ICD-11. It is characterized by a preoccupation that one is emitting foul odor or has a foul breath. The others do not perceive any such foul odor. Repetitive behaviors like changing clothes and repeatedly using perfumes are present. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.

References:

  • ↳ Olfactory Reference Syndrome
  • ↳ Other Options:
  • ↳ Other Options:
  • ↳ Option B. Antipsychotics: These are generally not the first-line treatment for ORS unless the patient has co-occurring psychotic symptoms, which are not described here.
  • ↳ Option B. Antipsychotics:
  • ↳ Option C. SSRI and exposure therapy: While exposure therapy can be a component of CBT, the primary approach here should involve general CBT strategies focused on cognitive restructuring and behavioral interventions.
  • ↳ Option C. SSRI and exposure therapy:
  • ↳ Option D. SSRI and ERP (Exposure and Response Prevention): ERP is specifically used in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). While ORS shares some similarities with OCD, standard CBT is more appropriate here.
  • ↳ Option D. SSRI and ERP (Exposure and Response Prevention):
  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 419.
  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 419.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child develops sudden onset of OCD symptoms following a streptococcal throat infection. This presentation is most consistent with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PANDAS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PANDAS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal Infections)
  • ➤ In a few cases, pediatric OCD may be precipitated or worsened by an infection involving Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus (GABHS). The hypothesis is that the infection initiates an autoimmune response in the basal ganglia, leading to the rapid onset of OCD symptoms and tics.
  • ➤ In a few cases, pediatric OCD may be precipitated or worsened by an infection involving Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus (GABHS).
  • ➤ The hypothesis is that the infection initiates an autoimmune response in the basal ganglia, leading to the rapid onset of OCD symptoms and tics.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with recurrent, intrusive sexual thoughts about children. He finds these thoughts distressing and has never acted on them. He fears he might harm a child. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management?

options.label: D
options.text: Generalized anxiety disorder; SNRI and supportive counselling

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) OCD; SSRI and ERP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intrusive, distressing thoughts about harming others, when inconsistent with one's values and leading to significant anxiety, are often symptoms of OCD. The first-line treatment includes SSRIs and cognitive-behavioral therapy, particularly exposure and response prevention.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman experiences recurrent flashbacks, nightmares, and avoidance of reminders three months after witnessing a severe car accident. Which of the following is not typically seen in this condition?

Ans. C) Hallucinations

  • ➤ Intrusion symptoms such as Flashbacks (patient may feel as if the traumatic event is happening again and may also act as if he is in the middle of the traumatic event Vivid memories of the trauma, nightmares about the trauma
  • ➤ Flashbacks (patient may feel as if the traumatic event is happening again and may also act as if he is in the middle of the traumatic event Vivid memories of the trauma, nightmares about the trauma

questions.text: According to ICD-11, which of the following is a characteristic symptom of Complex PTSD that distinguishes it from PTSD?
questions.correct_answer: C. Severe abnormalities of affect regulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Severe abnormalities of affect regulation

In addition to the symptoms of PTSD, the following symptoms are seen in complex PTSD Severe abnormalities of affect regulation (emotional regulation) The belief that one is defeated and worthless, feelings of shame or guilt Inability to feel close to others or sustain a relationship
  • ➤ A new diagnostic category in ICD-11

questions.text: A trauma victim is encouraged to immediately process the trauma and describe their thoughts and feelings about it. This approach is an example of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Debriefing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Debriefing involves the immediate processing and discussion of a traumatic event, aimed at helping individuals process their emotions and thoughts, though its effectiveness in preventing long-term psychological effects has been debated.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is preoccupied with the idea that he has a brain tumor despite multiple normal neurological examinations and brain scans. He spends excessive time researching brain tumors online. This presentation is most consistent with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Illness anxiety disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances. Management includes primarily psychotherapy (CBT), and pharmacotherapy for comorbid psychiatric disorders.
  • ➤ Preoccupation with illness- Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis)
  • ➤ Preoccupation with somatic symptoms- Somatic symptom disorder

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 453.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman suddenly develops paralysis of her left arm after a stressful event. Neurological examination and investigations are normal, and the symptoms do not conform to known anatomical pathways. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Conversion disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conversion disorder (ICD-11 uses the term ‘Dissociative neurological symptom disorder’) is characterized by symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found. The symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles. Patients may have ‘ la belle indifference ’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g. A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom. An important d/d of conversion disorder is acute intermittent porphyria
  • ➤ la belle indifference

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 454.

questions.text: A mother repeatedly brings her child to the hospital with symptoms she claims the child is experiencing, but medical evaluations consistently show no abnormalities. The child appears to be healthy when separated from the mother. This scenario is most suggestive of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Munchausen syndrome by proxy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Munchausen syndrome by proxy is characterized by the production of false symptoms or exaggeration of actual symptoms, in another person under the individual's care.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 457.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman suddenly travels to a distant city with no apparent reason and is found wandering confused about her identity. She has no recollection of how she got there. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dissociative fugue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dissociative fugue:
  • ➤ Sudden, unexpected travel (to an unexpected place but a place with emotional significance) May involve confusion about identity, the patient may be confused about his identity Basic self-care is maintained, and behaviour appears normal during travel There is amnesia for the period of travel. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue has been made a subtype of dissociative amnesia.
  • ➤ Sudden, unexpected travel (to an unexpected place but a place with emotional significance)
  • ➤ May involve confusion about identity, the patient may be confused about his identity
  • ➤ Basic self-care is maintained, and behaviour appears normal during travel
  • ➤ There is amnesia for the period of travel.
  • ➤ In DSM-5, dissociative fugue has been made a subtype of dissociative amnesia.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 438.

questions.text: During a cultural ceremony, a 40-year-old woman enters a state where she believes she's possessed by a spirit and acts accordingly. Her behavior is inconsistent with her usual self. This scenario is most suggestive of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Possession trance disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Possession trance disorder is characterised by trance states, along with an experience that the ‘personal identity’ has been replaced by an external ‘possessing identity’. Individuals’ behaviours are experienced as being controlled by ‘possessing identity’.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 444.

questions.text: A prisoner consistently gives incorrect but related answers to simple questions, such as saying the grass is blue when asked about its color. This behavior is most characteristic of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ganser's syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ganser’s syndrome:
  • ➤ Usually seen in prisoners (but is not exclusive to them) Characterised by “vorbeireden” (vorbeigehen) or approximate answers. Approximate answers are responses that, while not accurate, demonstrate a clear connection to the question, indicating that the question was understood. For instance, if asked about the color of the sky, a patient might respond with "red." Other symptoms include clouding of consciousness, and auditory and visual hallucinations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with confusion, ataxia, and bilateral 6th nerve palsy. His wife reports he has a history of heavy alcohol use. Lab results show elevated liver enzymes and macrocytic anemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer high-dose IV thiamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke’s encephalopathy is an acute complication due to thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. It is characterized by a triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia (6th cranial nerve palsy > 3rd nerve palsy), and ataxia in the context of chronic alcohol use. Immediate treatment with thiamine is essential.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with severe agitation, tachycardia, and hyperthermia. His friends report he took "molly" at a party. On examination, he has dilated pupils, muscle rigidity, and profuse sweating. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administer benzodiazepines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute MDMA toxicity, characterized by severe agitation, hyperthermia, and autonomic instability, the initial management should focus on administering benzodiazepines to control agitation, reduce hyperthermia, and prevent complications such as seizures and rhabdomyolysis.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 304.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder presents with progressive memory loss, confabulation, and difficulty walking. On examination, he has ataxia and nystagmus. Brain MRI shows: Which of the following best explains his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is a preventable condition linked to thiamine deficiency, often due to chronic alcohol use. In Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome, the neuropathological lesions are usually symmetrical and involve mammillary bodies.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 277.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain, diaphoresis, and agitation. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Urine toxicology is positive for cocaine. Which of the following mechanisms best explains his presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coronary vasospasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine-induced myocardial infarction is most commonly caused by coronary vasospasm, which can lead to ischemia and infarction even in the absence of significant atherosclerotic disease.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 304.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student is brought to the emergency room after being found unconscious at a party. His friends report he was drinking heavily and took some pills. questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a 30-year history of heavy alcohol use presents with progressive difficulty walking and slurred speech. On examination, he has nystagmus, dysmetria, and a wide-based gait. MRI shows: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic alcohol use can lead to alcoholic cerebellar degeneration, characterized by ataxia, gait disturbances, and cerebellar atrophy on imaging.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 279.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man develops sudden confusion, disorientation, and visual hallucinations following hip surgery. His symptoms fluctuate throughout the day. What is the most likely underlying mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cholinergic deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium is characterized by sudden onset & fluctuating course and presents with disturbances of consciousness (hallmark symptom), disorientation to time, place and person, perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations, impairment of attention, memory disturbances (recent and immediate, remote is intact), agitation (or hypoactivity), autonomic disturbances, sleep-wake cycle disturbances and sundowning phenomenon. Causes include:
  • ➤ Medical and surgical disorders/in hospitalised patients. Hip fractures, open heart surgery, severe burns, infections like pneumonia, postoperative patients, critically ill patients Alcohol and sedatives withdrawal On multiple medications (especially with anticholinergic actions) Sensory deprivation (e.g. Black patch delirium after cataract surgery)
  • ➤ Medical and surgical disorders/in hospitalised patients.
  • ➤ Hip fractures, open heart surgery, severe burns, infections like pneumonia, postoperative patients, critically ill patients
  • ➤ Alcohol and sedatives withdrawal
  • ➤ On multiple medications (especially with anticholinergic actions)
  • ➤ Sensory deprivation (e.g. Black patch delirium after cataract surgery)
  • ➤ Delirium is associated with cholinergic deficiency, primarily involving the Ascending Reticular Activating System.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 227.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a history of unstable relationships, recurrent self-harm, and chronic feelings of emptiness. She reports sudden shifts in her career goals and sexual identity. Her medical history reveals multiple emergency room visits for overdoses. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line psychotherapeutic approach?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dialectical behavior therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) is the first-line psychotherapeutic approach for borderline personality disorder, addressing emotional dysregulation, self-harm, and interpersonal difficulties.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 564.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a bar fight. He has a history of multiple arrests, and shows no remorse for his actions. Which of the following comorbid conditions is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Substance use disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) do not have regard for the rights of others and frequently violate them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviors such as theft, lying, truancy, and conning. They have a lack of remorse or guilt for their actions. Substance use disorder is the most common comorbid psychiatric condition observed in these patients. Treatment usually is psychotherapy. Medications like carbamazepine and β-blockers are occasionally used.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 569.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman avoids social situations due to fear of criticism and rejection. She desires close relationships but rarely initiates them. questions.explanation:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12 th edition, Page 573.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man reports episodes of consuming large amounts of food in short periods, accompanied by a feeling of loss of control. He feels guilty afterwards but does not engage in compensatory behaviors. His BMI is 32 kg/m2. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cognitive behavioral therapy

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting. She reports intense fear of gaining weight despite being underweight. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with excessive daytime sleepiness, sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by emotions, and vivid hallucinations while falling asleep. His sleep study shows reduced REM sleep latency. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypocretin deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of an uncomfortable sensation in her legs when trying to fall asleep, which is relieved by moving them. She reports difficulty initiating sleep due to this issue. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gabapentin

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin , are first-line treatments.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to episodes of sudden arousal from sleep, accompanied by screaming and intense fear. His parents report he has no recollection of these events the next morning. During which stage of sleep are these episodes most likely to occur?

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with persistent difficulty in maintaining erections during sexual activity. He reports normal morning erections and nocturnal erections. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports persistent lack of sexual desire and arousal, causing significant distress. She has no other medical conditions and is not on any medications. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line pharmacological treatment?

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl had normal development until age 6 months, after which she lost her acquired language skills, motor skills, and social interaction abilities. She now shows repetitive hand movements and impaired gait. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rett's Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rett's syndrome is a rare genetic disorder primarily affecting females , characterized by normal development till 5 months followed by deceleration of head circumference (resulting in microcephaly), loss of acquired hand skills and speech, poor gait, impairment in social interaction; restricted, repetitive behaviours & impairment of communication and language between 5-48 months. 75% of the patients have seizures. It is most commonly caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome . In DSM-5 and ICD-11, they are classified as autism spectrum disorders.
  • ➤ females

  • ➤ X chromosome

questions.text: A 35-year-old man, after being diagnosed with terminal cancer, engages in long discussions about the pathophysiology of his condition with his oncologist. Which defense mechanism is most likely at play here?

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of childhood sexual abuse has no recollection of the traumatic events. However, she experiences intense anxiety in intimate relationships. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

questions.text: According to Freud's structural theory of mind, which component operates on the "reality principle" and mediates between instinctual drives and moral constraints?

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with severe depression and high suicide risk is recommended for ECT. Which of the following is the anesthetic agent of choice for modified ECT?

questions.text: A patient with a phobia of dogs is gradually exposed to images of dogs, then videos, and finally a real dog, while practicing relaxation techniques. Which behavioral therapy technique is being used?
